awd_titl_txt: Ion channel contributions to developmental signaling in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
How does a single fertilized egg develop into a complex and perfectly patterned organism?  Cells need to divide, migrate to the correct location, take on the correct shape, and make all of the parts that are needed for their specialized role. Cells need to communicate with each-other to tell each-other where to go and what to become.  Over the last hundred years, researchers have used fruit flies to identify components of the “language” of cell-cell communication required for development of an animal. These developmental chemical signals are essentially the same between flies, worms, birds, and mammals.  Recently, the Bates lab discovered that electrical signals are also important for cells to communicate with each-other during development. These electrical signals are conducted through proteins called ion channels. The Bates lab used fruit flies to identify the types of ion channels that are important for a tissue to develop properly. The experiments will determine how some of these ion channels work with the chemical “language” for precise cell-cell communication. This project will also provide science communication classes for graduate students to give them skills to share their research with the community in various forums. In addition this grant will fund ongoing mentoring of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in their pursuits of scientific careers.

Ion channels have emerged as regulators of development, but the mechanism that connects ion channels to conventional developmental signaling pathways is far from clear. Using past NSF funding, the Bates lab showed that bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling requires the inwardly rectifying K+ channel (Irk2) to correctly specify development of the fruit fly wing. This project focuses on the provocative idea that bioelectric signals induce BMP and other developmental signaling. The objective of Aim 1 is to identify the ion channels that contribute to morphogenesis of the fruit fly wing, determine how they influence calcium transients in the wing disc, and determine how these changes to calcium activity impact canonical developmental signaling pathways. The team has chosen to prioritize Stim, Orai, Bestrophin 2, and SERCA for this analysis, and will follow up on other ion channels as time and resources allow. Aim 2 determines the molecular connection between calcium activity in the wing disc and Dpp/BMP release. In addition, broader educational goals include developing and teaching a science communication class for graduate students. Students will utilize skills gained from the class to reach adults in the community through a “science in the news” TED-talk type seminar series and at science comedy events. The Bates lab will continue to mentor high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to include them in transforming current understanding of developmental signaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For an animal to develop correctly, cells in the embryo have to send signals to each other to organize into the right pattern. If cells do not send the cells at the right time during development, the animal or person can have problems with how it develops, like limb defects or cleft lip and palate. How do cells in an embryo control when to send signals to each other? We can test these concepts using animals like fruit flies and mice. Using funding from NSF, we performed experiments to test how embryonic cells send signals to each other. We discovered that cells in a developing embryo use electrical changes to control when they send signals to each other. We discovered that electrical changes occur naturally in cells that are going to become a limb. Cells in the brain communicate with each other using electrical signals that raise calcium levels in the cell. The calcium then turns on SNAREs to send a chemical signal to the next cell. So next, we used genetic experiments to test if embryonic cells need SNAREs to form a limb correctly.  We found that blocking SNAREs causes limb defects. This means that embryo cells use some of the same tools to communicate with each other as the brain uses. We tested whether mammals (mice) need electrical signals to develop a palate correctly. We found that cells in the developing mouse palate are electrically active and they use that electrical activity to send a signal to make the mouse palate. This is really important because many medications that people take block electrical activity. Our work suggests that taking drugs that block electrical activity during pregnancy could cause abnormal development of the baby. In fact, we showed that vaping nicotine hurts fetal mouse bone and lung development by blocking electrical activity. Our NSF-funded work has been published in  scientific journals including Nature Communications, Developmental Biology, and Developmental Dynamics.

 

Progress in science depends upon funding from the taxpayer dollars. Therefore, we as scientists, have the responsibility to communicate what we learn and why it is important with the public. With funding from NSF, I developed a class teaching graduate students to communicate science with people who are not scientists. Students put into practice these skills by speaking at a local bookstore, making TikTok videos that were posted online, and writing articles for communities that they are a part of. My expertise in communicating science with the public allowed me to serve my community by giving talks at the local public libraries, public schools, on the news, and other public forums to help answer questions about current scientific issues that were important to people in 2020-2022. Because of my expertise in communicating science with people who are not scientists, I had the opportunity to present our work to US Representatives Diana DeGette and Jason Crow’s office to show how science about how cells communicate with each other during fetal development led to our work showing that vaping nicotine and taking cannabidiol during pregnancy can hurt the developing baby.

 

With NSF funding, I trained several undergraduate students to conduct scientific experiments, analyze their results, and present their projects to scientists and to the general public. Some of the students won awards for their presentations. Some of the undergraduate students I taught were able to publish their work in scientific articles that helped them get into graduate school or get the jobs that they wanted. With this NSF funding, we gave presentations to K-12 students to help them to see what scientists do and how they could pursue this career. We designed a week-long hands-on science internship for high school students. We paired each student with a graduate student mentor to help them apply for college. With NSF funding, I trained graduate (PhD) students to become independent scientists. Five of my PhD students graduated and are now serving as scientists in data analysis, biotech, Genetic Counseling, scientific research, and professor roles.
